object.property:
Alas! This not an X11 session, xsnow will probably not run.
If you want to try it anyway, set the environment variable XSNOW_FORCE_RUN, eg:
XSNOW_FORCE_RUN=1 xsnow
Or, you could force an X11 session, for example by tweaking /etc/gdm3/daemon.conf.
Ok, things are as they are.

If everything is ok, it is now snowing on your desktop.
 
 Using he tabs above (snow, Santa, scenery, wind) you are
 encouraged to define your own preferences.
 
 If xsnow misbehaves on your desktop, use the 'settings'
 tab to see if you can correct this.

 In every tab you find the following rescue buttons:
 Defaults: set default preferences for this tab.
 Vintage: set vintage preferences for this tab.
 All defaults: set default preferences for all (except settings) tabs.
 All vintage: set vintage preferences for all (except settings) tabs.

 Vintage preferences give the look and feel of the original
 xsnow, created in 1993 by Rick Jansen.
If everything is ok, it is now snowing on your desktop, and birds are flying.
You are encouraged to define your own preferences using the tabs above.
Use the settings tab if xsnow is misbehaving. Use the birds tab if birds are misbehaving.
In every tab you find the following rescue buttons:
Set default preferences for this tab.
Set vintage preferences for this tab.
Set default preferences for all (except settings) tabs.
Set vintage preferences for all (except settings) tabs.
Vintage preferences: the look and feel of the original xsnow, created in 1993 by Rick Jansen.
Apply defaults for all preferences (except settings).
If you feel the urge to make a donation to inspire the maintainer of xsnow, here is a paypal link.
Use vintage values for all preferences (except settings).
If the system is too busy, all panels get this color. You could adapt some things in "snow", "birds" or "settings".
If set, show snow blowing away.
If set, show fallen snow on windows.
If set, show fallen snow on bottom of the desktop.
If set, snow will collect on the trees.
The higher this setting, the more snow will be generated because of Santa ploughing, wind or disappearing windows.
The higher this setting, the more snow will collect on the windows. Note: in Wayland, there is no snow on the windows.
The higher this setting, the more snow will collect on the bottom of the desktop.
The higher this setting, the more snow will collect on the trees.
Apply default values for the preferences in this tab.
Apply vintage values for the preferences in this tab.
Apply defaults for all preferences (except settings).
Use vintage values for all preferences (except settings).
Size of snowflakes, works only for non-vintage snow flakes.
If set, try to show fluff on fallen snow and trees if possible.
Santa with Dasher, Dancer, Prancer, Vixen, Comet, Cupid, Dunder and Blixem.
Santa using the train with two reindeers.
Santa using the train with one reindeer and Rudolph.
Tiny Santa with two reindeers and Rudolph.
Small Santa with two reindeers and Rudolph.
Santa with two reindeers and Rudolph.
Santa with Dasher, Dancer, Prancer, Vixen, Comet, Cupid, Dunder, Blixem and Rudolph.
Apply default values for the preferences in this tab.
Apply vintage values for the preferences in this tab.
Apply defaults for all preferences (except settings).
Use vintage values for all preferences (except settings).
To show or not to show scenery.
Vintage tree, you can set the color.
Apply default values for the preferences in this tab.
Apply vintage values for the preferences in this tab.
Apply defaults for all preferences (except settings).
Use vintage values for all preferences (except settings).
Bottom percentage of screen available for scenery.
To allow overlap or not when placing scenery.
Compose here your favorite celestial conditions
Apply default values for the preferences in this tab.
Apply vintage values for the preferences in this tab.
Apply default values for all preferences (except settings).
Apply vintage values for all preferences (except settings).
If set, there will be wind.
The higher this setting, the more the wind will whirl.
This setting determines how many seconds pass between two gusts of wind.
Force a gust of wind immediately.
To show or not show stars.
To show or not to show meteorites,
To show or not show moon
To show or not to show halo around moon.
Apply defaults for all preferences (except settings).
Use vintage values for all preferences (except settings).
Apply default values for the preferences in this tab.
Apply vintage values for the preferences in this tab.
If set: show no Santa, snow or scenery.

Viewing distance. NOTE: Santa has no knowledge of viewing distance, so when birds are following Santa, the relative positions of Santa and birds will be temporarely out of sync when you change the viewing distance. This is only noticeable when the birds are following Santa.
Distance used to get the desired number of neighbours.
Eagerness to concentrate on common attraction point
Desired number of birds. If zero, no birds are shown.
Number of nearest neighbours the birds should look at.
Give the birds a fancy color.
Anarchy level: the higher, the more anarchy
Eagerness to keep desired distance to neighbours.
Eagerness to adjust speed to neighbours.
Speed of birds in arbitrary units.
Influence the size of the birds.
Show the point where the birds want to go.
Birds are attracted by an attraction point. Here you can choose to let Santa be the attraction point.
Transparency of painted items: 0: no transparency. 100: fully transparent, you will see nothing!
Use this if snow falls below the bottom of your screen, or fallen snow hides something that should not be hidden.
Use this if no snow collects on your windows, or if snow collects separated from your windows. Some basic window managers need this setting (e.g. TWM needs in general a value of 25 .. 28).
The higher, the smoother xsnow will run, but will also use more cpu power.
Apply default values for the preferences in this tab.
Apply vintage values for the preferences in this tab.
Apply defaults for all preferences (except settings).
Use vintage values for all preferences (except settings).
Toggle between xsnow's own colors and standard colors. Activated: use xsnow colors. Deactivated: use default colors.
Use all workspaces to snow in. NOTE: this doesn't work properly in enlightenment.

When activated, it will be snowing below your windows, else it will be snowing upon you windows too. On some desktop environments, when snowing above your windows you will not be able to click on any window. Therefore, you will be asked to click a button, to be sure that things are OK.
To make sure you can click.
